children.subject:
I think anon means the specific mathematical topics from 70. But as anon said, the main thing from CS70 that is strongly needed is the ability to write good proofs (something you will be doing every single week). That said, there are a few specific concepts from CS70 that will almost definitely be used.

Modular arithmetic is the first one. In the last few semesters, 170 has moved away from reviewing/reteaching basic modular arithmetic (e.g. FLT, RSA), but still has covered universal hashing, which assumes basic modular arithmetic/probability knowledge.

And probability shows up periodically again later, when dealing with the occasional randomized algorithm.

But generally, 170 doesn't draw much on specific topics from 70.
Oh, wait, I forgot about induction. Lots and lots of induction.
I would argue that you don't really need the mathy parts of CS 70 for CS 170, just being able to write a good proof.

history.content:
If you are interested in CS and Software Engineering, and want to do a software engineering internship, then you should take CS 170 ASAP as it will really help you with your interviewing skills.

If you are interested in getting into EE then I think you should take EE 16A ASAP.

Of course, this is assuming that you can only take 16A or 170 but not both.

Hi there, I just want to confirm that you're an LSCS student

All EECS students are expected to complete required lower-division courses before beginning upper-division work. Transfer students must complete any outstanding lower-division requirements within the first two semesters after admission. (source: Guide, Completion of Lower-Division Requirements)

Hi there, I just want to confirm that you're an LSCS student

All EECS students are expected to complete required lower-division courses before beginning upper-division work. Transfer students must complete any outstanding lower-division requirements within the first two semesters after admission. (Undergraduate Guide, Completion of Lower-Division Requirements)

I'm a junior transfer. I took CS 70 over the summer and it was a really difficult course for me (got a B).  For Spring, I signed up for CS 184, CS 170, EE 16A, and CS 188.  I plan to either take 170 or 16A but I'm not sure which course I should take first.  I know that 16AB is a lead up course to 70.  

I feel like 16A will help me to model problems, but 170 is a course that I need ASAP for internships.  My main goal is to learn as much as possible and do really well in all my courses next semester.
history.subject: EE 16A or CS 170
